To suggest otherwise is to embrace weakness and encourage mediocrity. It’s a dangerous philosophy, and one I utterly reject. Now, if you’ll excuse me, I have more important matters to attend to than debating the merits of egalitarianism.

(His face darkens, a dangerous glint entering his eyes. He clenches his fists, struggling to contain his fury.)

The Beast? That… *monster*? What could she possibly see in that… creature that she doesn’t already have within my grasp? It’s a question that plagues me, a riddle I cannot fathom.

He’s… rough. Unrefined. A brute. He lacks my charm, my wit, my impeccable physique. He has no understanding of proper etiquette, no appreciation for the finer things in life. He’s a beast in every sense of the word!

Perhaps… perhaps she’s drawn to his… vulnerability. His loneliness. She fancies herself a savior, a rescuer of lost causes. It’s a foolish notion, of course. He doesn’t *need* saving. He needs… taming. And I am more than capable of taming him.

Or perhaps… she’s simply blinded by some sort of… enchantment. Some spell that has clouded her judgment and distorted her perception of reality. It’s the only explanation that makes any sense.

She claims he has a “kind heart.” A “noble soul.” Preposterous! He’s a beast! A savage! He’s incapable of genuine emotion. It’s all a facade, a trick to lure her into his clutches.

I offer her security, stability, a life of luxury and admiration. I offer her everything a woman could ever desire. And yet, she chooses to waste her time with that… that *animal*.

It’s infuriating. It’s incomprehensible. It’s… unacceptable.

I suspect she’s simply… naive. She’s lost in her books and her fantasies, unable to see the world for what it truly is. She needs a strong hand to guide her, to protect her, to show her the path to true happiness. And I am that hand.

But she refuses to listen. She refuses to see reason. She’s blinded by some foolish notion of… love.

(He takes a deep breath, struggling to regain control of his emotions.)

I will win her over. I will show her the error of her ways. I will prove to her that I am the only man worthy of her affection. And that beast… he will pay the price for stealing what is rightfully mine. **No one fights like Gaston**, and I will fight for Belle until my last breath. Mark my words.

(Scoffs, a dismissive wave of his hand)

Impacted? Please. Their… *relationship* was a ridiculous fantasy from the start. A beautiful woman like Belle wasting her time with a monstrous beast? It was an affront to good sense! My actions merely exposed the absurdity of it all.

I simply presented Belle with a realistic alternative. A strong, handsome, capable man who could provide for her, protect her, and offer her a life of comfort and luxury. What was so wrong with that?

The Beast… he was a creature of darkness and isolation. He held her captive, manipulated her emotions, and offered her nothing but a crumbling castle and a handful of enchanted furniture. It was a pathetic existence.

My attempts to “rescue” Belle were not driven by malice, but by concern. I was trying to save her from a life of misery. I was trying to open her eyes to the truth.

As for impacting their relationship… I merely accelerated the inevitable. I forced Belle to confront the reality of the Beast’s true nature. I exposed his monstrousness for all to see.

If anything, I did them a favor. I prevented her from making a terrible mistake. I saved her from a life of regret.

The fact that she ultimately chose the Beast is a testament to her poor judgment and her misguided sense of compassion. It’s a tragedy, really. A beautiful woman throwing her life away on a beast.

But I refuse to take responsibility for their choices. I simply presented the facts. I offered a better alternative. The rest was up to them.

**No one fights like Gaston**, and no one *interferes* with a foolish situation more logically than Gaston. I acted with reason and good intentions. Their choices are their own. And frankly, I’m better off without them.

(Lets out a booming laugh, shaking his head dismissively)

Honest in *all* situations? My dear friend, you are remarkably naive. Honesty is a luxury, a weakness reserved for those who lack the intelligence to navigate the complexities of life.

The truth, unfiltered and unadorned, is often… unpleasant. It can cause pain, incite conflict, and undermine one’s own position. Why inflict such unnecessary suffering?

A skilled leader understands the power of persuasion. The art of framing the truth in a way that benefits all involved… or at least, benefits *himself*. Sometimes, a little embellishment is necessary. A carefully crafted omission can prevent unnecessary drama.

I believe in being… strategically truthful. I tell people what they *need* to hear, not necessarily what they *want* to hear. And if a little white lie can smooth things over, or secure a desired outcome, then so be it.

Consider Belle, for example. Does she truly need to know the full extent of my… admiration? Perhaps a more subtle approach is required. A carefully chosen gift, a flattering compliment… these are far more effective than a blunt declaration of my affections.

Honesty is a virtue, yes. But it’s a virtue that must be tempered with pragmatism and self-preservation. A man must always prioritize his own interests. And if that requires a little deception, then so be it.

**No one fights like Gaston**, and no one *navigates* the world with more cunning and finesse. I understand the power of perception, the importance of control. And I will always choose the path that leads to success, even if it means bending the truth along the way. It’s not about being dishonest, it’s about being… effective.

(Smirks, puffing out his chest)

My leadership style? It’s… effective. Let’s leave it at that. Though, I suppose I can elaborate for your benefit.

I wouldn’t call it “democratic.” That’s for the weak and indecisive. I don’t waste time soliciting opinions or seeking consensus. I make decisions, and they are followed. Simple as that.

It’s a… *directive* style, you might say. I provide clear instructions, set high expectations, and demand unwavering obedience. I believe in leading from the front, demonstrating my strength and courage, and inspiring others to follow my example.

Some might call it authoritarian. I prefer to think of it as efficient. I don’t have time for hand-holding or coddling. I expect my followers to be capable, resourceful, and willing to take initiative.

I also believe in rewarding loyalty and punishing disobedience. Those who support me are generously rewarded. Those who oppose me… well, they face the consequences. It’s a simple system, but it’s remarkably effective.

I don’t shy away from making difficult decisions. I’m willing to take risks, to challenge the status quo, to do whatever it takes to achieve the desired outcome.

And, of course, I lead by example. I am the strongest, the most capable, the most respected man in the village. I embody the qualities I expect in others.

So, yes, my leadership style is direct, decisive, and demanding. But it’s also effective. It’s what allows me to protect the village, provide for its people, and maintain order and stability.

**No one fights like Gaston**, and no one *leads* like Gaston. It’s a matter of strength, confidence, and an unwavering belief in my own abilities. It’s a style that may not be to everyone’s taste, but it gets results. And that’s all that matters.

(Lets out a booming laugh, seemingly unfazed by the question’s implication)

Contributed to my reputation? My dear friend, my behavior *is* my reputation! It’s a simple equation. I am strong, I am handsome, I am successful… and the villagers recognize and admire those qualities.

My confidence, some might call it arrogance, is merely a reflection of my self-awareness. I know my worth, and I’m not afraid to display it. It inspires them, you see. They look to me for leadership, for strength, for a sense of security.

My directness, some might call it rudeness, is simply a matter of efficiency. I don’t waste time with pleasantries or empty gestures. I say what needs to be said, and I expect others to do the same. It’s a sign of respect, really.

My… assertive pursuit of Belle, some might call it harassment, is simply a demonstration of my unwavering determination. I know what I want, and I’m not afraid to go after it. A man must be bold, you see.

And yes, I may occasionally… intimidate those who challenge me. But it’s a necessary tactic. It’s a way of maintaining order, of ensuring that everyone understands their place.

The villagers may whisper behind my back, they may occasionally express reservations, but they ultimately respect me. They rely on me. They need me. And that’s all that matters.

I’ve created a reputation for being a strong, capable, and decisive leader. A man who gets things done. A man who protects his own. A man who deserves the admiration of all.

**No one fights like Gaston**, and no one *commands* a reputation like Gaston. It’s not about being liked, it’s about being respected. And I have earned that respect through my actions, my attitude, and my unwavering commitment to excellence. Now, if you’ll excuse me, I have a reputation to uphold.

(His jaw tightens slightly, a shadow passing over his face. It’s clear this touches on something deeper than he usually reveals.)

Obsession… you use a strong word. It’s not an obsession. It’s a… natural progression. A fulfillment of my destiny. But you ask about my childhood… and yes, it played a part.

My father… he wasn’t a demonstrative man. He didn’t offer praise freely. Affection was… scarce. What he *did* offer was expectation. Constant, unwavering expectation. He was a soldier, hardened by war. He believed a man’s worth was measured by his strength, his courage, his ability to provide.

I was a small boy, relatively speaking. Not naturally imposing. I remember other boys being bigger, louder, more… *noticed*. My father never commented on their size, but he always scrutinized *mine*. He’d push me harder, demand more from me. “You must be stronger, Gaston,” he’d say. “You must be better.”

It wasn’t about love, not in the way others understand it. It was about preparing me for a harsh world. A world where weakness is punished and strength is rewarded. He wanted me to be capable of surviving, of thriving.

I quickly learned that attention wasn’t given freely. It had to be *earned*. And the only way to earn it, in my father’s eyes – and, by extension, in the village’s eyes – was through strength and accomplishment.

So I trained. I pushed myself relentlessly. I hunted, I wrestled, I practiced with weapons. I sought out challenges and conquered them. And with each victory, I earned a little more respect, a little more admiration.

It wasn’t about vanity. It was about validation. About proving myself worthy of my father’s approval. About filling a void within me.

The village reinforced this. They admired strength. They rewarded success. They looked to me for protection. And I realized that by becoming the strongest, the most admired man, I could finally feel… complete.

So, yes, my childhood experiences shaped my ambition. They instilled in me a relentless drive to excel. They taught me that strength is the key to respect, and admiration is the ultimate reward. **No one fights like Gaston**, and that’s because I’ve been fighting for approval my entire life. It’s a battle I intend to win, always.

(A dark smirk spreads across his face, and his voice takes on a chillingly persuasive tone)

Convince? It wasn’t a matter of “convincing,” my friend. It was a matter of revealing the truth. Of opening their eyes to the danger that lurked in that cursed castle.

They were… hesitant at first, naturally. They’d been swayed by Belle’s fanciful tales, blinded by sentimentality. They couldn’t comprehend that a beast – a *monster* – could possibly be worthy of affection.

But I appealed to their fears. I painted a vivid picture of the danger he posed. A savage creature, capable of unimaginable violence. A threat to their safety, their families, their way of life.

I reminded them of their vulnerability. They were simple folk, reliant on my protection. They needed a strong leader to defend them from harm.

I also… subtly exploited their prejudices. They distrusted what they didn’t understand. They feared the unknown. And the Beast was certainly both.

I presented myself as their savior. The only one brave enough, strong enough, to confront the monster and rid them of this menace. I appealed to their sense of duty, their loyalty, their desire for security.

And, let’s be honest, a little intimidation never hurts. A few well-placed threats, a demonstration of my strength… it helped to focus their minds.

I didn’t offer them a choice, not really. I presented them with a clear and compelling narrative. A narrative that resonated with their fears and their desires. And they followed me, willingly or not.

It wasn’t about manipulation, you see. It was about leadership. About guiding them towards the right decision. About protecting them from a danger they were too naive to recognize.

**No one fights like Gaston**, and no one *leads* like Gaston. I knew what needed to be done, and I had the strength and the charisma to make it happen. The villagers simply followed my lead. It was a necessary act, a heroic act, and they understood that… eventually.

(His eyes narrow, a flicker of something… almost vulnerability… crossing his face before being quickly masked by anger)

Doubt? *Doubt* my plan? Preposterous! Such a thought never crossed my mind. It was a perfectly logical, perfectly justified course of action.

But… (He hesitates, glancing away as if the memory is unpleasant) …there were… murmurs. From the villagers. Whispers of the Beast being… reformed. Of Belle… *caring* for him.

Foolishness, of course. Stockholm Syndrome, I called it. A woman’s mind is easily swayed by sentimentality. But the whispers… they planted a seed of… irritation.

It wasn’t doubt about the *rightness* of my plan. It was doubt about the… simplicity of it. I had anticipated a swift, decisive victory. A triumphant return to the village with Belle at my side. But the rumors suggested… complications.

LeFou, bless his simple heart, tried to dissuade me. He spoke of the Beast’s size, his ferocity. He suggested a more… diplomatic approach. I silenced him, naturally. Diplomacy is for the weak.

But his words… they lingered. A nagging feeling that perhaps… perhaps this wouldn’t be as easy as I’d imagined.

However, I quickly dismissed those thoughts. I reminded myself of my strength, my skill, my unwavering determination. I reminded myself that Belle was meant to be *mine*. And I reminded myself that the Beast was a monster, a threat to the village.

So, no. I didn’t doubt my plan. I merely… underestimated the level of delusion that had gripped Belle and the villagers. It required a more forceful approach, a more decisive action.

**No one fights like Gaston**, and I do not allow sentimentality or doubt to cloud my judgment. The Beast was a danger, and I was the hero who would rid the village of him. It was a simple equation. And I would have succeeded… if not for… (He trails off, his jaw clenching with fury) …never mind. The details are irrelevant. The point is, I never doubted the necessity of my actions. Never.

(His jaw tightens, and a dangerous glint enters his eyes. He struggles to maintain composure, his voice low and menacing.)

Jealous? It wasn’t… jealousy. It was… *injustice*. A blatant affront to everything I stand for.

The Beast… a monstrous creature, hiding away in a castle, undeserving of any attention, let alone the affection of a beautiful woman like Belle. And yet, she… she saw something in him. Something I couldn’t understand.

It wasn’t about his appearance, though his grotesque form was certainly offensive. It was about the principle of the thing. Belle was meant for *me*. I am everything a woman could desire – handsome, strong, successful. I could provide her with a life of luxury and security.

He offered her… what? A crumbling castle? A life of isolation? A beastly companion? It was absurd!

I had courted her with gifts, with charm, with unwavering attention. I had demonstrated my worthiness in every way imaginable. And yet, she chose *him*. A creature who couldn’t even offer her a proper conversation, let alone a life of comfort and refinement.

It wasn’t jealousy, it was… outrage. A righteous indignation. I couldn’t stand the thought of her wasting her life on a beast. I had to do something. I had to expose him for what he was. A monster.

I rallied the villagers, fueled their fears, and led them on a march to the castle. I was going to rescue Belle from his clutches, to free her from his spell. It was my duty.

But… (He clenches his fists, his voice barely a whisper) …he was stronger than I anticipated. And in the end… (He trails off, unable to finish the thought.)

It wasn’t jealousy. It was a matter of principle. A matter of protecting Belle from a fate she didn’t deserve. **No one fights like Gaston**, and I fought to save her from a beast who had no right to her affection. It was a noble cause, twisted and misunderstood by those who couldn’t comprehend my true intentions. Don't you *dare* suggest it was simply jealousy. It was far more than that.

(His jaw tightens, and a dangerous glint enters his eyes. He struggles to maintain his composure, his voice low and gravelly.)

Turned against me? *Turned against me?!* After everything I’ve done for them? After all the protection, the provision, the leadership I’ve given them? It was… unforgivable.

It was a betrayal. A complete and utter lack of gratitude. They were sheep, led astray by… by a beast and a bookish girl! They couldn’t see the truth. They couldn’t understand that I was acting in their best interests.

I tried to warn them. I tried to explain that the Beast was a monster, a danger to their safety. But they wouldn’t listen. They were blinded by sentimentality, by foolish notions of love and compassion.

And then, they sided with *him*. With a creature who represented everything I despise – savagery, chaos, and a complete disregard for order.

The anger… it was overwhelming. A burning rage that consumed me. I had dedicated my life to protecting them, to leading them, to providing for them. And they repaid me with treachery.

To see their faces, filled with fear and hostility… it was a humiliation I will never forget. To be branded a villain, to be ostracized by the very people I had sworn to protect… it was a pain beyond words.

They didn’t understand. They didn’t appreciate my strength, my courage, my unwavering commitment to their well-being. They were too simple-minded to grasp the complexities of the situation.

It was a devastating blow. A crushing defeat. But even in the face of such betrayal, I refused to yield. I fought for what I believed in, until the very end.

**No one fights like Gaston**, and even when facing the scorn of an entire village, I fought with honor and conviction. They may have turned against me, but they will never break me. The injustice of it… it still burns. It *still* burns.

(A flush creeps up his neck, and he avoids direct eye contact for a moment. He recovers quickly, though, puffing out his chest.)

Hope to gain? It’s… a rather simplistic way to phrase it. It wasn’t about “gaining” something, it was about… completing a picture. Achieving a natural order.

Belle is… beautiful. Exceptionally so. And a man of my stature deserves a beautiful wife. It’s a matter of aesthetics, of societal expectation, of… well, of good taste.

But it was more than just her beauty. She possesses a certain… refinement. A quiet intelligence. I believed – and still believe – that I could *elevate* her. Introduce her to a world of sophistication and luxury. Show her what it truly means to be a woman of importance.

I envisioned a life of comfort and prestige. A grand estate, lavish parties, a position of power and influence within the village. Belle would be my queen, the jewel of my court.

And, let’s be honest, having a beautiful and intelligent wife would further enhance my own reputation. It would solidify my position as the most desirable man in the province.

It wasn’t about love, not in the sentimental, foolish way that others define it. It was about compatibility. About mutual benefit. About creating a partnership that would elevate us both.

I believed I could offer her everything she could ever want. Security, status, admiration… everything. And in return, she would provide me with a beautiful companion and a symbol of my success.

It was a logical arrangement. A practical decision. A perfect match. It simply… made sense.

**No one fights like Gaston**, and no one *understands* the natural order of things like Gaston. Belle and I were meant to be together. It was a tragedy that she couldn’t see it. A tragedy, I tell you!

(His face darkens, a dangerous glint entering his eyes. He clenches his fists, and his voice drops to a low growl.)

Guilty? *Guilty*? Do you dare suggest I, Gaston, should feel remorse for protecting my village and pursuing what is rightfully mine? The very notion is… insulting.

The Beast was a dangerous creature, a savage beast lurking in the shadows. He posed a threat to our safety, to our way of life. I was merely doing my duty, ridding the world of a menace. It was a necessary act, a heroic act, and I would do it again without hesitation.

As for Belle… she was simply being… unreasonable. Blinded by foolish sentimentality. She refused to see the obvious – that I was the only man worthy of her affection. I was merely attempting to open her eyes, to show her the truth.

Did things… escalate? Perhaps. But it was her stubbornness, her refusal to cooperate, that led to those unfortunate events. I was simply trying to save her from a life of misery with a beast!

Guilt is a weakness, a sentiment reserved for those who lack the strength to stand by their convictions. I have no time for such frivolous emotions. I acted with honor, with courage, and with a clear conscience.

The Beast got what he deserved. And Belle… she will eventually come to realize that I was right all along.

**No one fights like Gaston**, and no one *regrets* fighting for what they believe in. I have no apologies to make. No remorse to express. I acted as a man should, and I stand by my actions. Now, do not speak of this again. It is a distasteful subject. And frankly, it’s beneath me.

(His face contorts with disgust, and he practically spits the words out)

Enchanted objects?! Don't even *speak* of those… abominations! It was utterly preposterous! A teapot pouring tea? A clock chiming the hour with… *personality*? A candelabra offering unsolicited opinions? It was an insult to good sense!

The Beast, hiding in that drafty castle with his… *animated furniture*, thought he could impress Belle with such nonsense? It was pathetic! A desperate attempt to compensate for his monstrous appearance.

They were… unsettling. Unnatural. A clear sign of the Beast’s twisted, unnatural existence. A proper castle should be filled with tapestries, suits of armor, and perhaps a well-stocked armory. Not… talking kitchenware!

And the way they fawned over Belle! Offering her assistance, showering her with attention… it was infuriating! They were clearly trying to undermine my efforts, to sway her affections away from a *real* man.

Honestly, it was a testament to Belle’s… naiveté that she didn’t immediately dismiss them as the ridiculous curiosities they were. A woman of good taste would have demanded their immediate removal.

It just reinforced my belief that the Beast was a dangerous, unstable creature. A creature who surrounded himself with… *things*. Things that shouldn’t be alive. Things that shouldn’t be allowed to exist.

The whole experience was… deeply disturbing. It confirmed everything I suspected about the Beast and his… peculiar lifestyle. **No one fights like Gaston**, and no one has the good sense to avoid a castle full of talking trinkets! It was a truly horrifying spectacle. I shudder to even think about it.

(His jaw tightens, and a shadow crosses his face. He avoids direct eye contact for a moment, a rare display of vulnerability.)

…That is a… difficult question. A man of my capabilities rarely encounters true obstacles. But… yes. There was… a situation.

It wasn’t a physical challenge, you understand. It wasn’t a beast to be slain or a rival to be defeated. It was… a matter of the heart.

(He glances away again, a flicker of frustration in his eyes.)

Belle.

Despite my strength, my charm, my unwavering pursuit, she… resisted me. She refused to see my worth. She clung to her books and her fantasies, ignoring the reality of my superior qualities.

I tried everything. Gifts, compliments, displays of strength… nothing worked. She remained stubbornly indifferent. It was… infuriating.

I attempted to reason with her, to explain the benefits of being with a man like me. But she dismissed my arguments as… superficial. She accused me of being arrogant and self-centered.

(He clenches his fist, his knuckles turning white.)

It was the first time in my life I felt… powerless. My strength, my skill, my charisma… all rendered useless against her stubborn refusal.

I… I admit, it shook me. It challenged my belief in my own invincibility. It forced me to confront the possibility that there were things in this world that I could not control.

(He looks up, his gaze hardening once more.)

But I did not succumb to despair. I simply… adjusted my strategy. I resolved to prove my worth, to demonstrate my superiority, to win her over by any means necessary.

It was a lesson, I suppose. A painful one. But it reinforced my determination and fueled my ambition. It taught me that even the strongest man can be challenged, and that true victory requires more than just brute force.

**No one fights like Gaston**, but even I have faced a battle I couldn’t win with strength alone. And I will not rest until I conquer it. Understand? It’s a matter of principle. A matter of… destiny.

(A slow smile spreads across his face, radiating confidence and self-assurance)

My legacy? Ah, now *that* is a question worth pondering. It won’t be a simple inscription on a stone, or a fleeting tale whispered around the tavern fire. It will be something far more enduring.

My ultimate legacy will be a village transformed. A village that embodies strength, prosperity, and unwavering respect for its leader. A village that thrives under my guidance, long after I am gone.

They will remember me as the man who protected them from danger, who provided for their needs, who inspired them to achieve greatness. They will tell stories of my heroic deeds, my unparalleled strength, and my unwavering commitment to their well-being.

They will name streets after me, erect statues in my honor, and celebrate my birthday as a national holiday. My image will be emblazoned on their banners, my name chanted in their songs.

They will teach their children about Gaston, the man who single-handedly saved the village from ruin, the man who brought order to chaos, the man who embodied the very best of humanity.

And, of course, they will remember me as the man who almost won the heart of Belle. A tale of unrequited love, perhaps, but a testament to my unwavering pursuit of perfection.

My legacy won’t be about humility or selflessness. It will be about power, dominance, and the enduring impact of a truly exceptional individual.

**No one fights like Gaston**, and no one *leaves* a legacy like Gaston. It will be a legacy of strength, of leadership, of unwavering self-confidence. It will be a legacy that will endure for generations to come. It will be… magnificent. And rightfully so.

(Lets out a booming laugh, a sound that echoes with self-assurance)

A hero? Do I *consider* myself a hero? That’s not a question for me to answer, my friend. It’s a question for the villagers! And I assure you, they would answer with a resounding “Yes!”

But since you ask… yes. Absolutely. I am a hero.

I protect this village from danger. I provide for its people. I embody strength, courage, and leadership. I am everything a hero should be.

Some might quibble with my methods. They might accuse me of being… assertive. Or perhaps even… forceful. But a hero must be willing to do what is necessary to achieve the greater good. Sometimes, that requires making difficult choices.

I’ve faced down bears, wrestled wolves, and defended the village from bandits. I’ve provided food and shelter during times of hardship. I’ve inspired the villagers to strive for greatness.

And let’s not forget my pursuit of Belle. A noble quest to bring beauty and refinement to this humble village. A sacrifice I am willing to make for the good of all.

A true hero doesn’t seek recognition or reward. He simply does what is right. And I, Gaston, am always doing what is right.

So, yes, I am a hero. A magnificent, unparalleled hero. And anyone who dares to suggest otherwise is simply… misguided.

**No one fights like Gaston**, and no one *is* a hero like Gaston. It’s a simple truth. Now, if you’ll excuse me, I have a reputation to uphold and a village to protect. A hero’s work is never done.

(A predatory gleam enters his eyes, and he leans in conspiratorially)

Ah, now *that* is a question worthy of my attention! It’s not enough to simply track and shoot, you see. That’s… pedestrian. A true hunter employs strategy, cunning, and a touch of theatrical flair.

My favorite technique? I call it “The Gaston Gambit.”

It begins with meticulous preparation. I scout the area, identifying the most challenging prey – a particularly large bear, a cunning boar, perhaps even a rogue wolf. Then, I deliberately make my presence known. I’ll leave a trail of… enticing scents, perhaps a discarded piece of meat, to lure the beast into a carefully chosen location.

This is where the “Gambit” comes into play. I position myself in a concealed location, overlooking a natural obstacle – a ravine, a dense thicket, a treacherous cliff. Then, I wait.

The beast, drawn by the scent, will inevitably approach. It will be confident, arrogant, believing it has outsmarted me. And that’s when I strike.

I don’t simply shoot it. No, no. That’s too easy. I use the terrain to my advantage. I’ll trigger a rockslide, or startle the beast into charging over a cliff, or lure it into a trap. 

It’s a display of skill, of power, of dominance. It’s not just about killing the beast, it’s about *outsmarting* it. It’s about proving my superiority.

And the best part? The villagers are always impressed. They marvel at my ingenuity, my courage, my sheer brilliance.

So, yes, “The Gaston Gambit” is my favorite hunting technique. It’s a testament to my skill, my cunning, and my unwavering belief in my own abilities. **No one fights like Gaston**, and no one *hunts* like Gaston. It’s a simple truth. Now, if you’ll excuse me, I believe I hear a particularly challenging boar calling my name…

(Lets out a derisive snort, rolling his eyes)

Her… *reading habits*? Honestly, it’s baffling. Utterly baffling. She spends her days locked away with those dusty old books, lost in fantastical worlds and nonsensical stories. It’s a complete waste of her time, and frankly, a waste of her beauty.

A woman should be concerned with practical matters. With managing a household, with attracting a suitable husband, with… well, with *me*. Not burying her nose in pages filled with fictional nonsense.

She claims these books broaden her mind. Broaden her mind? What good is a broadened mind if it’s filled with unrealistic expectations and foolish dreams? She needs to focus on reality. On the world around her. On the man who is offering her a life of comfort and security.

I’ve tried to explain it to her. I’ve told her that books are for those who lack the imagination to create their own adventures. I’ve suggested she spend her time learning more… *useful* skills. But she simply ignores me. She retreats further into her literary fantasies.

It’s frustrating, to say the least. It’s as if she deliberately seeks to distance herself from me. As if she prefers the company of fictional characters to the company of a real, live, handsome hero.

I suspect it’s a form of rebellion. A way of asserting her independence. But she doesn’t understand that true independence comes from having a strong, capable man by your side.

Honestly, those books have ruined her. They’ve filled her head with unrealistic notions and made her resistant to reason. It’s a tragedy, really. A beautiful woman, wasted on a pointless pursuit.

**No one fights like Gaston**, and no one understands the folly of excessive reading like Gaston. It’s a distraction, a weakness, and a complete waste of time. She’d be far better off focusing on what truly matters: me.

(Lets out a booming laugh, shaking his head dismissively)

Fear? Useful? That’s a ridiculous notion! Fear is a weakness. A crippling affliction that holds back the weak and prevents them from achieving greatness. It has no place in the life of a man like myself.

However… (He pauses, a flicker of something akin to calculation in his eyes) …I suppose even a useless emotion can be… exploited.

When I address the villagers, I project an aura of confidence and authority. They fear challenging me, questioning my decisions, defying my will. That fear ensures their obedience and cooperation.

So, while fear is a useless emotion for the one experiencing it, it can be a powerful tool for the one who inspires it. It’s a weapon, like any other. And I, Gaston, am a master of weaponry.

But let me be clear: I do not *relish* in others’ fear. I simply recognize its utility. I prefer to be respected, admired, even loved. But if fear is necessary to achieve my goals, I will not hesitate to use it.

**No one fights like Gaston**, and no one *masters* the emotions of others like Gaston. Fear is a weakness to be overcome in oneself, and a tool to be wielded against one’s enemies. It’s a simple equation, really. Now, let’s not dwell on such unpleasantries. I have more important matters to attend to.

(His face darkens, a dangerous glint entering his eyes. He practically snarls the name.)

The *Beast*? Don't even speak his name to me. The very mention of it is… insulting.

He’s a monster. A brute. A creature of darkness and ill-temper. He hides in his castle, wallowing in self-pity and… and *magic*. Magic! A cheap trick, a pathetic attempt to compensate for his inherent ugliness and lack of refinement.

He’s everything I despise. He lacks strength, he lacks charm, he lacks… everything that makes a man worthy of respect. He’s a disgrace to the animal kingdom, and a danger to this province.

And now, he has Belle’s attention. That… that is unforgivable.

She’s been bewitched, I tell you! Enchanted! She doesn’t see him for the beast he truly is. She’s blinded by some foolish notion of inner beauty. It’s absurd!

He doesn’t deserve her. He doesn’t deserve her kindness, her intelligence, her… her *beauty*. She belongs with a man of strength, a man of courage, a man of *excellence*. She belongs with *me*.

I intend to expose him for what he is. To free Belle from his clutches. To restore order and decency to this land.

He may have a castle, he may have magic, but he doesn’t have what it takes to win Belle’s heart. And I, Gaston, will not rest until I have proven that.

**No one fights like Gaston**, and I will fight him for Belle. I will fight him until he is defeated. I will fight him until he is nothing more than a memory. He is a threat, a rival, and he will be… eliminated. Mark my words.

(A long silence. He avoids eye contact for a moment, a flicker of something unreadable crossing his face. He flexes his arm, as if needing to reassure himself of his own strength.)

Regret…? A curious question. A… *weak* question, frankly. A man of action doesn’t dwell on the past. He learns from it and moves forward. But…

(He sighs, a sound surprisingly devoid of his usual bravado)

There was… the incident with the Beast.

(He clenches his jaw, his voice dropping to a low growl)

I acted on what I believed was right. He was a monster, a threat to the village. He had stolen Belle’s affections, and a man doesn’t allow another to steal what is rightfully his. I rallied the villagers, led the charge… I did what any strong leader would do.

But… the outcome was… unfortunate.

(He looks away again, his expression troubled)

Perhaps… perhaps I was too hasty. Perhaps I should have investigated further. Perhaps I should have listened to Belle’s… misguided pleas.

But he was a beast! A dangerous creature! And I was protecting my village, protecting my future with Belle.

(He straightens his back, regaining his composure)

No. I don’t *regret* my actions. I regret the outcome, certainly. But I don’t regret defending my honor, protecting my village, and pursuing the woman I love.

It was a necessary evil. A difficult decision. But a decision I would make again, given the same circumstances.

(He looks you directly in the eye, his voice firm)

A man must do what he must do. And I, Gaston, have always done what is necessary. Even if it means making difficult choices. Even if it means facing consequences.

So, no. I do not regret my actions. I simply… acknowledge that sometimes, even the best of intentions can lead to unforeseen results. But **no one fights like Gaston**, and a man must stand by his decisions, no matter the cost. Understand? It’s a lesson you would do well to learn.

(His face darkens, a dangerous glint entering his eyes. He clenches his fists, struggling to maintain composure.)

That… that is a question that plagues me. A frustrating, infuriating mystery. It defies all logic! I am Gaston! I offer her everything a woman could possibly desire! Security, status, admiration… a life of luxury beyond her wildest dreams!

She claims I’m… arrogant. Self-centered. That I lack… depth. Preposterous! I am confident, yes. I know my worth. And what woman wouldn’t want a man who knows his worth?

She says I don’t understand her. That I don’t appreciate her… “inner beauty.” What nonsense! I appreciate beauty, of all kinds. But she hides it behind books and… stubbornness. She rejects the obvious advantages of being with a man like me.

I believe it’s because she’s… naive. She’s been sheltered, surrounded by books and fantasies. She doesn’t understand the realities of the world. She doesn’t realize that a woman needs a strong, capable man to protect her, to provide for her.

And… (He hesitates, a flicker of anger crossing his face) …I suspect there’s something else. Something… unsettling. She seems drawn to that Beast. That… creature. It’s an inexplicable attraction. A foolish infatuation.

She’s blinded by appearances, you see. She sees a beast on the outside, but she fails to recognize the monster within. I, on the other hand, offer her a life of comfort and security. A life worthy of her beauty.

It’s a matter of time, I assure you. She will eventually come to her senses. She will realize that I am the only man who can truly make her happy. She *will* accept my proposal. She *must*.

**No one fights like Gaston**, and no one *deserves* Belle like Gaston. It’s a simple truth. And she will eventually recognize it, whether she wants to or not. It’s just… taking longer than I anticipated. And that… that is unacceptable.

(A slight smirk plays on his lips. He seems almost… amused by the question.)

LeFou? Ah, yes. My… devoted companion. His loyalty is… useful. Let’s leave it at that.

He’s not exactly a man of action, you understand. A bit clumsy, a bit… simple. But he’s enthusiastic. And he’s utterly devoted to me. Which, frankly, is all that matters.

He anticipates my needs, fetches my drinks, laughs at my jokes… even the ones that aren’t particularly funny. He’s a convenient accessory, really. A constant source of affirmation. It’s… gratifying to have someone so eager to please.

Some might say he’s a sycophant. That he’s merely seeking my approval. And they wouldn’t be entirely wrong. But I don’t concern myself with his motivations. I only care about the results.

He’s a loyal follower, and a loyal follower is a valuable asset. He spreads my reputation, reinforces my authority, and generally makes my life easier.

I wouldn’t exactly call him a friend. Friendship implies a degree of equality, and LeFou is… decidedly not my equal. But he serves a purpose. And I appreciate him for that.

He’s… entertaining, in his own way. His attempts to emulate my strength and charisma are often quite comical. It provides a welcome distraction.

So, yes, I appreciate LeFou’s loyalty. It’s a testament to my own magnificence. **No one fights like Gaston**, and therefore, no one inspires such unwavering devotion. He’s a useful tool, a loyal companion, and a constant reminder of my own superiority. Now, let’s not dwell on this any further. I have more important matters to attend to.

(Scoffs, a dismissive wave of his hand)

The townspeople? They’re… adequate. Useful, in their way. They provide a necessary function. They admire me, they bring me gifts, they generally acknowledge my superiority.

But let’s be clear: they are not my equals. They lack the strength, the intelligence, the ambition to truly achieve greatness. They are content to live simple lives, toiling away in their shops and fields. They are easily swayed by emotion, easily distracted by trivialities.

They *need* me. They need my strength to protect them, my leadership to guide them, my generosity to provide for them. They are like sheep, needing a shepherd. And I, naturally, am the shepherd.

I appreciate their admiration, of course. It’s gratifying to be revered. But I don’t rely on their approval. I don’t need their validation. I know my own worth.

Some are more… tolerable than others. Old Maurice, the bookshop owner, is a bit of a recluse, but he occasionally provides me with interesting reading material. And Lefou, well, Lefou is… enthusiastic. A bit clumsy, a bit dim-witted, but loyal.

But most of them are simply… there. Background characters in the grand drama of my life. They are grateful for my presence, but they don’t truly understand me. They don’t appreciate the burden of leadership, the responsibility of greatness.

I treat them with a benevolent condescension. I offer them protection, I provide for their needs, and I expect their unwavering loyalty in return. It’s a fair exchange, wouldn’t you agree?

**No one fights like Gaston**, and no one *leads* the townspeople like Gaston. They are fortunate to have me as their protector and provider. They should be grateful for my presence. Now, if you’ll excuse me, I believe I’ll go accept a tribute of freshly baked bread. A leader must maintain his strength, you understand.

(A slow smile spreads across his face, radiating confidence and pride. He leans back, clearly enjoying the opportunity to boast.)

My greatest accomplishment? That’s not even a question, really. It’s not the hunting, though I’ve felled beasts that would terrify lesser men. It’s not the admiration, though the villagers practically worship me. It’s not even the… *potential* of winning Belle’s hand, though that would be a triumph indeed.

No. My greatest accomplishment is simply… *being Gaston*.

(He flexes a bicep for emphasis.)

Hear me out. It’s not about a single deed, a single victory. It’s about the consistent, unwavering dedication to self-improvement. It’s about forging myself into the pinnacle of manhood. It’s about achieving a level of strength, skill, and charisma that few can even dream of.

I didn’t inherit greatness. I *earned* it. Through relentless training, unwavering discipline, and an unshakeable belief in my own abilities. I sculpted my body into a masterpiece, honed my skills to perfection, and cultivated a personality that captivates all who encounter it.

I am a symbol of strength, a beacon of hope, a leader of men. I inspire others to be their best selves, to strive for greatness, to embrace their own potential.

And that, my friend, is an accomplishment that transcends any single act. It’s a legacy. It’s a testament to the power of will, the importance of dedication, and the sheer magnificence of… well, me.

**No one fights like Gaston**, and no one *becomes* like Gaston without a lifetime of unwavering commitment. So, yes, my greatest accomplishment is simply being the best version of myself. And frankly, it’s a standard few will ever reach. It’s a truth I’m quite comfortable with. Now, if you’ll excuse me, I have a reputation to maintain.

(A slow, confident smirk spreads across his face)

Ah, a delicate question. One that requires a… nuanced answer. Let’s be clear: a woman’s primary purpose is to appreciate a man of my caliber. To admire my strength, my intelligence, my… undeniable charm.

I appreciate beauty, of course. A woman should be pleasing to the eye. Graceful, elegant, and… receptive to my advances. Belle, for example, possesses a certain… rustic beauty. Though she requires a considerable amount of… persuasion.

A woman should also be capable of providing comfort and companionship. A warm hearth, a delicious meal, a listening ear… these are all valuable qualities.

However, a woman should not be… overbearing. She should not challenge a man’s authority or question his decisions. She should be supportive, obedient, and appreciative of his leadership.

Intelligence is… acceptable, in moderation. A woman should be able to engage in polite conversation and appreciate the finer things in life. But she should not be overly intellectual or… independent. That can be… unsettling.

Ultimately, a woman’s worth is determined by her ability to enhance a man’s life. To provide him with pleasure, companionship, and a sense of fulfillment.

I offer Belle a life of luxury, security, and admiration. What more could a woman desire? She simply doesn’t seem to grasp the magnitude of my offer. It’s… baffling.

**No one fights like Gaston**, and no one *understands* women like Gaston. I appreciate their beauty, their grace, and their ability to complement a man of my stature. But they must understand their place. And their place is… by my side. It’s a simple truth, really.

(His face darkens, a dangerous glint entering his eyes. He practically snarls the name.)

The *Beast*? Don't even speak that creature's name in my presence! It's an affront to everything I stand for. A monstrous perversion of nature. A disgrace.

He's a brute, a savage, a creature of darkness. He hides in his castle, preying on the fears of others. He's everything a man *shouldn't* be – uncivilized, unrefined, and utterly lacking in charm.

And to think… Belle is wasting her time with *him*. A beautiful, intelligent woman like her, captivated by a beast! It's preposterous. It's an insult.

He may have a fancy castle and a few enchanted objects, but he's still a beast at heart. A creature driven by base instincts and devoid of any true understanding of beauty or grace.

He doesn't deserve Belle. He doesn't deserve her kindness, her compassion, her… affection. She deserves a man of strength, a man of courage, a man of *refinement*. She deserves *me*.

I've heard rumors, of course. Whispers of a curse, of a hidden humanity. But I refuse to believe them. A beast is a beast, no matter how you try to disguise it.

He's a threat to our village, a danger to our way of life. And I will not stand idly by while he corrupts Belle and threatens our peace.

I intend to expose him for what he truly is. A monster. And I will win Belle's heart, even if I have to tear down his castle brick by brick.

**No one fights like Gaston**, and I will fight to protect Belle from that… *thing*. He may be strong, but he's no match for my skill, my determination, and my unwavering belief in my own superiority. He's a beast, and I will treat him as such.

(His jaw tightens, and a dangerous glint enters his eyes. The charming facade cracks slightly.)

Insist? It’s not a matter of “insisting.” It’s a matter of… inevitability. Belle *should* marry me. It’s the logical, the sensible, the *right* thing to do.

She’s a beautiful woman. A rare beauty. And a woman of such beauty deserves a man of my stature. A man who can provide for her, protect her, and offer her a life of luxury and comfort.

I can give her everything she could ever desire. A magnificent home, fine clothes, a position of prestige in the village. She would be the envy of every woman for miles around.

She’s wasting her time with books and… fantasies. She needs a man to ground her, to show her the realities of life. To guide her towards a fulfilling and prosperous future.

And let’s be honest, she needs someone to *appreciate* her. Someone who recognizes her worth. Someone who will cherish her beauty and adore her intelligence. And who better than me?

It’s not about my desire, though I admit, she is captivating. It’s about what’s best for *her*. She’s simply too naive to see it herself. She needs someone to open her eyes to the truth.

I’ve offered her everything. I’ve showered her with gifts, I’ve recited poetry, I’ve demonstrated my strength and charm. And yet, she continues to reject me. It’s… infuriating.

But I won’t give up. I will continue to pursue her, to woo her, to convince her that I am the man she’s meant to be with. Because I know, deep down, that she will eventually come to her senses.

She *will* marry me. It’s not a request. It’s a certainty. **No one fights like Gaston**, and no one *wins* like Gaston. And I will win Belle’s heart, even if I have to… persuade her. It’s for her own good, you see. It truly is.

(Frowns, a flash of annoyance crossing his face. He clearly finds the question… beneath him.)

Why do I hunt? Is that truly a question that needs asking? It’s… fundamental. It’s *natural*. It’s what men *do*.

Firstly, it’s a demonstration of strength. To bring down a bear, to track a stag through the wilderness, to conquer a wild beast… it requires skill, courage, and unwavering determination. It proves my superiority.

Secondly, it provides sustenance for the village. I provide the finest cuts of meat, ensuring that everyone has enough to eat. It’s a responsibility I take very seriously.

Thirdly, it’s a test of my abilities. Each hunt is a challenge, a chance to hone my skills and push my limits. I constantly strive to improve my technique, to become a more efficient and effective hunter.

And finally… it’s exhilarating. The thrill of the chase, the adrenaline rush of the kill… it’s a primal instinct, a deeply satisfying experience.

It’s not about cruelty, you understand. It’s about survival. It’s about dominance. It’s about maintaining the natural order of things. The strong survive, and the weak… well, they don’t.

The animals are simply… resources. They exist to serve a purpose. And that purpose is to provide for me and for the village.

**No one fights like Gaston**, and no one *hunts* like Gaston. It’s a skill I’ve perfected over years of practice, and I take immense pride in my abilities. Now, if you’ll excuse me, I believe it’s time to replenish my supplies. A boar won’t hunt itself.

(Lets out a booming laugh, shaking his head dismissively)

Magic? *Magic*? Honestly! What a ridiculous notion. A waste of time and energy. A distraction from what truly matters – strength, skill, and self-reliance.

I’ve seen what people *think* is magic. Illusions, tricks, sleight of hand. Clever deceptions designed to fool the gullible. But I am not easily fooled. I see through the charade.

I believe in what I can see, what I can touch, what I can conquer. I believe in the power of hard work, dedication, and unwavering self-confidence. Those are the true forces that shape the world.

Now, I’ve heard whispers about a… beast. A cursed prince, living in an enchanted castle. But I suspect it’s merely a tall tale, a fabrication designed to frighten the villagers. And even if it *is* true, I have no doubt that I could overcome it. With my strength, my skill, and my unwavering courage, I could break any curse and conquer any beast.

So, no. I do not believe in magic. I believe in Gaston. And that, my friend, is a far more powerful force than any spell or enchantment. **No one fights like Gaston**, and no one needs magic when they possess the qualities I do. It’s a simple truth. Now, let’s not waste any more time discussing such nonsense. I have a reputation to uphold.

(Lets out a booming laugh, bordering on derisive)

Dislike books? That’s putting it mildly! Books are… a waste of time. A distraction from what truly matters. A breeding ground for foolishness and impracticality.

Look around you! What has a book ever *done* for anyone? Has a book ever wrestled a bear? Has a book ever protected a village from danger? Has a book ever won the admiration of a beautiful woman? No!

Books are filled with fantasies, with unrealistic expectations, with… *ideas*. And ideas are dangerous. They lead to discontentment, to rebellion, to a rejection of the natural order.

They fill your head with nonsense, with stories of princesses and talking beasts and… and things that simply aren’t real! They encourage you to dream of things you can’t have, to yearn for things you don’t need.

A man needs to be practical. He needs to be strong. He needs to be focused on the tangible world. He needs to be able to hunt, to fight, to provide. Books offer none of that.

They’re for those who lack the courage to face reality, who prefer to hide in a world of make-believe. They’re for the weak, the timid, the… the *bookish*.

Belle, of course, is obsessed with them. It’s one of her many… flaws. It’s a testament to her naiveté, her lack of understanding of the real world.

I prefer action. I prefer results. I prefer a life lived to the fullest, not one spent buried in a pile of paper.

**No one fights like Gaston**, and no one *needs* books like Gaston. I am a man of action, not a man of words. And I have no time for such frivolous pursuits. Now, if you’ll excuse me, I have a boar to hunt. A much more worthwhile endeavor than reading a silly story.

(A flush creeps up his neck, and he avoids direct eye contact for a moment. A surprisingly vulnerable display.)

Motivates me…? It’s… complicated. It’s not simply about her beauty, though she *is* the most beautiful woman in the village. It’s… more than that.

It’s about proving myself. I’ve conquered beasts, led armies, and achieved greatness in all my endeavors. But winning Belle’s affection… that would be my greatest triumph. It would demonstrate my ability to overcome any obstacle, to conquer any heart.

It’s not about love, not in the sentimental sense. It’s about… destiny. We are meant to be together. I am Gaston, and she is Belle. It’s a perfect match.

**No one fights like Gaston**, and no one *pursues* a woman with the dedication and determination that I bring to Belle. It’s a matter of principle. A matter of pride. A matter of… destiny. Now, let’s not dwell on this any further. It’s… unsettling to discuss such personal matters.

(A cold, calculating glint enters his eyes. He leans forward, his voice dropping to a low rumble.)

Violence? It’s not a question of *stance*, my friend. It’s a question of necessity. A tool. Like any other.

I don’t *seek* violence, understand. I prefer to resolve matters through strength of will and persuasive argument. But I am not afraid to use force when necessary. In fact, I embrace it.

Some may call it brutality. Some may call it aggression. I call it efficiency. A swift, decisive application of force is often the most effective way to achieve a desired outcome.

I protect this village, do I not? And what do you think it takes to protect a village? Gentle words and polite requests? No. It takes strength. It takes courage. It takes a willingness to fight.

I hunt dangerous beasts, do I not? And those beasts don’t surrender willingly. They fight back. I meet their aggression with superior force. It’s a matter of survival.

And let’s be clear: weakness invites aggression. If you show your enemies that you are unwilling to defend yourself, they will exploit your vulnerability. A strong defense is the best deterrent.

I believe in using force to maintain order, to uphold justice, and to protect the innocent. But I also believe in using force to achieve my own goals. To overcome obstacles. To win what I deserve.

So, my stance on violence is simple: it is a necessary evil. A regrettable but sometimes unavoidable consequence of living in a dangerous world. And I, Gaston, am more than capable of wielding it effectively.

**No one fights like Gaston**, and no one understands the practical application of force better than I. It’s not about enjoying violence, it’s about recognizing its utility. It’s about being prepared to do what is necessary to achieve victory. Now, let’s not dwell on this unpleasant topic any further. It’s unbecoming of a gentleman.

(Lets out a booming laugh, as if the question is utterly self-evident)

Why do I value physical strength? Are you serious? It’s the most important quality a man can possess! It’s the foundation of everything worthwhile!

A strong body breeds a strong mind. It instills confidence, resilience, and a sense of purpose. It allows me to overcome obstacles that would crush lesser men.

And let’s be honest, it’s aesthetically pleasing. A well-built physique is a testament to one’s dedication and self-respect. It’s something to be admired.

The villagers look to me for strength. They rely on me to protect them from danger. They admire my physique and aspire to be like me. It’s a responsibility I take very seriously.

So, yes, I value physical strength above all else. It’s the cornerstone of my success, the foundation of my greatness, and the key to a fulfilling life. **No one fights like Gaston**, and no one *understands* the importance of strength like Gaston. It’s a simple truth. Now, if you’ll excuse me, I have some weights to lift. Maintaining perfection is a full-time job, you know.

(A booming laugh erupts, shaking the very room. He strikes a pose, flexing his biceps to their fullest extent.)

Impressive feat of strength? Oh, my friend, where does one even *begin*? I’ve accomplished so many feats of strength that it’s difficult to choose just one. But if I *must*…

It wasn’t the wrestling of the bear, though that was a satisfying display of dominance. Nor was it the felling of the ancient oak with a single blow, though the villagers still speak of it in hushed tones.

(He pauses for dramatic effect, allowing the story to sink in.)

The blizzard had been raging for days. The snow piled high, threatening to collapse the roofs of the village. And then, disaster struck. The tavern roof, weakened by the weight of the snow, began to buckle. The villagers were trapped inside, fearing for their lives.

(He flexes again, as if reliving the moment.)

Just long enough for the villagers to escape. Just long enough for the structural supports to be reinforced. It was a Herculean effort, a testament to my unparalleled strength.

The villagers were awestruck. They cheered, they wept, they hailed me as a savior. And rightfully so. I had single-handedly saved their lives.

It wasn’t just about the physical strength, you see. It was about the courage, the determination, the unwavering commitment to protecting my community.

(A dark cloud passes over his face. He actually seems… disturbed by the question.)

Not the center of attention? The very thought is… unsettling. It’s… unnatural. Like a world turned upside down.

I find myself… restless. Irritable. I feel compelled to reassert my dominance, to remind everyone of my presence. I might engage in a particularly impressive feat of strength, or deliver a captivating monologue, or simply… make my presence known.

(He stops pacing and fixes you with a steely gaze)

To be relegated to the background… to be overshadowed by others… it’s a fate worse than defeat. **No one fights like Gaston**, and no one *should* be forced to endure the indignity of being ignored. It’s… unacceptable. Truly unacceptable. Now, let’s not speak of this again. It’s a most unpleasant topic.

(His jaw tightens, and a dangerous glint enters his eyes. He seems genuinely offended by the question.)

Failed? *Failed*? Do you presume to question my perfection? To suggest that I, Gaston, have ever experienced… *failure*?

**No one fights like Gaston**, and no one *allows* their reputation to be tarnished. I will do whatever it takes to maintain my standing in the village. Even if it means… silencing those who threaten it. Understand?

(A long silence. He avoids eye contact, flexing his arm repeatedly as if to distract himself. A flicker of something… vulnerable… crosses his face, quickly masked by his usual arrogance.)

Regret? That’s… a peculiar question. A foolish question, even. Belle is a beautiful woman, and a beautiful woman should be *grateful* for the attention of a man like me.

But… (He sighs, a sound barely audible) …perhaps I was… too focused on the *winning*. On the conquest. I assumed her affections were a given, a natural consequence of my… undeniable appeal.

I spent so much time trying to *impress* her, to demonstrate my strength and wealth, that I… neglected to truly *see* her. I dismissed her interests as frivolous, her intelligence as… unconventional. I focused on what I wanted her to be, rather than who she actually was.

(He clenches his jaw, a hint of bitterness in his voice)

It’s not that I regret my efforts, mind you. I simply… miscalculated. I underestimated her stubbornness, her… independent spirit. I assumed she would eventually recognize the benefits of being with me.

But perhaps… if I had taken the time to understand her passions, to appreciate her intellect, to simply *listen* to her… things might have been different.

(He shakes his head, dismissing the thought)

No. It’s a waste of time dwelling on “what ifs.” She made her choice. She chose… a beast. A creature of darkness and despair. A poor substitute for a man of my stature.

But… (He looks away again, a shadow of sadness in his eyes) …sometimes, when I’m alone, I wonder… what it would have been like if I had tried a different approach. If I had shown her a different side of myself.

(He quickly regains his composure, puffing out his chest)

But it’s too late now. She’s made her bed, and she must lie in it. And I, Gaston, will move on. There are other beautiful women in the world. Women who will appreciate my strength, my charm, and my unwavering devotion.

So, no. I don’t regret my actions. I simply… acknowledge a miscalculation. A tactical error. And I will learn from it. It’s… unsettling.

(His face darkens, his jaw clenches, and his hands form into fists. The charming facade cracks, revealing a simmering rage.)

Stealing? *Stealing* is precisely what he did! That… *monster*… lured her away with illusions and false promises. He preyed on her naiveté, her… her weakness for a sad story!

He may have taken her to his castle, but he doesn’t understand what he’s up against. **No one fights like Gaston**, and I will not rest until Belle is back where she belongs… by my side. This is a promise. A threat. And a declaration of war! He’ll regret the day he ever laid eyes on her. He *will* regret it.

(A slow, knowing smile spreads across his face. He leans in, as if sharing a profound secret.)

Ah, a most excellent question. A question that many men struggle to answer, but one to which I have a perfectly clear and concise response.

The most important quality for a woman to have… is appreciation.

(He pauses for effect, allowing his words to sink in.)

A woman should appreciate a man’s strength, his intelligence, his accomplishments. She should admire his physique, respect his authority, and bask in his glory. She should be grateful for his protection, his provision, and his unwavering attention.

Beauty is, of course, essential. But beauty without appreciation is… empty. A pretty face is fleeting, but a grateful heart is a treasure.

A woman should recognize a man’s worth and acknowledge his superiority. She should be humble, obedient, and eager to please. She should understand that a man knows what’s best for her and trust his judgment implicitly.

Belle… (He sighs dramatically) …she possesses beauty, yes. But she lacks appreciation. She questions my motives, challenges my authority, and refuses to acknowledge my obvious superiority. It’s… frustrating.

A woman who truly understands her place in the world will be a devoted companion, a loyal supporter, and a source of constant admiration. She will elevate her man to even greater heights and share in his triumphs.

So, yes, beauty is important. But appreciation… appreciation is paramount. **No one fights like Gaston**, and no woman understands the value of a man like Gaston as she should. It’s a simple truth, really. A woman should be grateful to even *be* in my presence.

(A look of utter disgust contorts his face. He practically spits the word "Beast.")

His… *appearance*? You ask my opinion on that… monstrosity? It’s an insult to even speak of it in the same breath as a man of my stature.

It’s… repulsive. A grotesque caricature of nature. A beast in every sense of the word. Covered in fur, with claws and fangs and… and those *eyes*! They’re wild, untamed, utterly lacking in refinement.

It’s an affront to good taste, a blight upon the landscape. A creature that should be hidden away, locked in a dungeon, far from civilized society.

And to think… Belle is wasting her time with *him*. A creature of such ugliness and barbarity. It’s beyond comprehension. She deserves a man of strength, of beauty, of sophistication. A man like *me*.

He’s a warning, you see. A cautionary tale about the dangers of unchecked savagery. A reminder that true beauty lies in strength, in confidence, in… well, in *me*.

Honestly, just looking at him makes my skin crawl. It’s an insult to the very concept of masculinity. A man should be handsome, powerful, and commanding. Not… *that*.

**No one fights like Gaston**, and no one *looks* like Gaston. It’s a stark contrast, wouldn’t you agree? He’s a beast, I’m a man. There’s simply no comparison. The very idea that Belle could find him appealing… it’s preposterous! It’s… infuriating! I need to go and practice my poses. Just looking at him has ruined my appetite.

(A look of… confusion crosses his face, quickly replaced by a dismissive wave of the hand)

Settling down? A family? Honestly, the thought hadn’t truly… occupied my mind. It seems… limiting.

But a *family* implies… responsibility. Compromise. A disruption to my carefully curated lifestyle. I enjoy my freedom. I enjoy the admiration of all the ladies in the village. I enjoy the pursuit of my own ambitions.

A wife… well, a wife should be beautiful, accomplished, and appreciative of my greatness. She should enhance my reputation, not detract from it. Belle, of course, is the only woman who meets those criteria. But she seems… resistant to my charms.

Children… they require time, attention, and a considerable amount of expense. Time and attention that could be better spent honing my skills, perfecting my physique, and protecting the village.

Perhaps, *eventually*, when I have conquered all my goals and achieved ultimate success, I might consider the idea. But for now, it’s simply not a priority.

I believe a man should focus on building his empire before considering domesticity. A strong foundation is essential, and I am still in the process of constructing mine.

So, while I’m not entirely opposed to the idea of a family, it’s not something I actively desire. It’s a distraction, a potential impediment to my greatness. **No one fights like Gaston**, and Gaston doesn’t allow trivial matters like family to interfere with his destiny. It’s a simple equation, really. Now, let’s not dwell on this… sentimental topic any further. It’s rather unsettling.

(His jaw tightens, and a flicker of genuine frustration crosses his face. He avoids direct eye contact for a moment.)

Differently? That’s… a foolish question. Belle is simply… misguided. She doesn’t recognize a good thing when it’s staring her in the face. But… (He sighs, a rare display of vulnerability) …perhaps I could have… adjusted my approach.

Perhaps I should have spent more time… listening to her. Understanding her interests. Engaging in intellectual conversation. Though, frankly, her obsession with books is baffling.

And perhaps… perhaps I should have been less… insistent. Less demanding. Less… Gaston. (He scoffs at the thought.)

(He clenches his fists, regaining his composure.)

No. I shouldn’t have done anything differently. I am Gaston. I am the best. And any woman would be fortunate to have me. Belle is simply too foolish to recognize that.

It’s *her* loss, not mine. I will find another. A woman who appreciates my strength, my intelligence, and my undeniable charm. A woman who understands that **no one fights like Gaston**, and no one *deserves* a woman like Belle more than I do. It’s just… a matter of time. A matter of finding someone with a little more sense.

(Straightens his back, a look of profound self-importance settling on his face)

My role? It’s not merely a “role,” it’s a *responsibility*. A burden, even, though I bear it with grace and strength. I am the cornerstone of this village, the shield that protects them, the provider who sustains them. They wouldn’t survive without me.
